div3.head: The Roanoke Island Affair.
div3.p:
--The Congressional Committee appointed to investigate the causes of our disaster on Roanoke Island in February last, has made its report.
The following is the conclusion, from which it will be seen that the whole blame is thrown upon the shoulders of Gen. Huger and Secretary Benjamin.

It is apparent to the committee, from the correspondence on file of Gen. Wise with the Secretary of War, Gen. Huger, his superior Officer the Governor of North Carolina, and other persons, that he was fully alive to the importance of Roanoke Island, and has devoted his whole time, and energies, and means, to the defences of that position; and that he is in no way responsible for the unfortunate disaster which befell our forces upon that island on the 7th and 8th of February. But the committee cannot say the same in reference to the efforts of the Secretary of War and the commanding officer at Norfolk, Gen. Sugar.
It is apparent that the Island of Roanoke was important for the defence of Norfolk and that Gen. Huger had under his command at that point upwards of 15,000 men, a large supply of armament and ammunition, and could have thrown in a few hours a large reinforcement upon Roanoke Island, and that himself and the Secretary of war had timely notice of the entire inadequacy of the defences, the want of men and mu of war, and the threatening attitude of the enemy.
But Gen. Huger and the Secretary of War paid no practical attention to those urgent appeals of Gen. Wise, sent forward none of his important requisitions, and permitted Gen. Wise and his inconsiderable force to remain to meet at least fifteen thousand men, well armed and equipped.
If the Secretary of War and the commanding General at Norfolk had not the means to reinforce General Wise, why was he not ordered to abandon his position, and save his command?
But, upon the contrary, he was required to remain, and sacrificed his command, with no means to his insulated position to make his escape in case of defeat.
The committee, from the testimony, are therefore constrained to report that, whatever of blame and responsibility is justly attributable to any one for the defeat of our troops at Roanoke Island, on the 8th of February, 1862, should attach to Major-General B. Huger and the late Secretary of War, J. P. Benjamin.

div3.head: An Incident of the battle of Shiloh.
div3.p: --The Mobile Tribune has the following from a gentleman who participated in the battle:

q.p:
During the engagement Colonel Stewart W. Cayce's horse was killed, when he got his foot entangled some way in the stirrup, and white disengaging himself he was taken prisoner by a Federal lieutenant, to whom he surrendered his sword and sash and then stood a few paces off as a prisoner of war between the deadly fires of both armies.
Shortly afterwards he inquired of the lieutenant, "what are you going to do?" The lieutenant remarked, turning his head towards him, "In a few minutes we will make a retreat and I'll take you with me." At that instant a ball from our side struck him in the eye and he fell dead from his horse.

Immediately after the enemy retreated, when Col. Cayce, with all the coolness that becomes a brave man, deliberately divested the dead officer of his (Col. Cayce's) own property, his sword, and seeing two Federals near by, grasped them and took them prisoners to his own command.

div3.head: Prater for the "Virginia."
div3.p: --The following form of prayer has been issued by Rt. Rev. Stephen Elliott, Episcopal Bishop of Georgia, to be used in all the Churches of his Diocese:

q.p:
Eternal Lord God, who alone spreads out the Heavens and rulest the raging of the sea; who hasts, compassed the waters with bounds, until day and night come to an end, be pleased to receive into Thy almighty and most gracious protection the persons of Thy servants, the officers and crews of our fleet, and especially of the Virginia, now engaged in active service.
Preserve them from the dangers of the sea, and from the violence of the enemy; give them victory in their various conflicts, that they may be a safeguard unto the Confederate States of America, and a security for such as pass on the seas upon their lawful occasions; may they then return in safety to enjoy the blessings of the land with the fruits of their labor, and with a thankful remembrance of Thy mercies to praise and glorify Thy holy name through J Christ our Lord — Amen.

div3.head: Bank of St. John's, Fla.
div3.p:
--A rumor having been current that this Bank had been captured by the Yankees, we may state that the specie belonging to the Bank had been taken to the upper part of Georgia, and all the other valuables to Lake City, before the arrival of the enemy at Jacksonville.
The Cashier states the affairs of the Bank to be in as sound a condition as they ever have been, and that the Bank would be glad to exchange Confederate Treasury Notes, or Charleston or Savannah funds, for any of its outstanding bills.

div3.head: A Profitable paper.
div3.p:
--Considerably more than half the gross receipts of the London Gazette are profits.
In the last financial year the receipts from advertisements and sale of the Grisette were £ 17 978; the paper and printing cost £ 4,617, and the management £ 1,981, leaving a profit for that year of no less than £ 11,880, which was paid over to the public purse.
One gentleman, with a salary of £ 750, has the triple distinction of editor, manager, and publisher; and ree clerks, an index-maker, and a warehouseman, complete the establishment.

div3.head: Deserving a Passion.
div3.p:
--Mrs. Keziah Walters, a widow lady living in the vicinity of Kingsville, in this county has six sons in the volunteer service, and the seventh, a hearty looking boy of fifteen, came down on Monday last, and volunteered to take the place of some man who had been called out in the militia.
This poor woman, deserves a pension.
Having learned that her circumstances in life are bumble, without her knowledge we introduce her case to the notice of the patriotic and benevolent--Sufoth (Va) Sun.

A negro man belonging to Mrs Harvey, of Roanoke county, Va., a few days ago white-washed himself, put on woman's clothing, and took the case for Tennessee.
The ingenious nigger succeeded in getting as far as Bristol, where a discovery was made which led to his speedy return to his owner.
The wheat crop in the neighborhood of Statesville, N C., is unusually promising at the present time.
Henry E. Prentiss, the Yankee General captured at Shiloh, is a native of Maine and a West Point graduate of the class of 1831.

div3.head: Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--To be commanded by Prof. R. T. Massie, of the University of Virginia.
A No. 1 Company, a No. 1 Battery, and a No. 1 Captain secured!--With permission from the Secretary of War, granted in a letter of the 20th of January last, in which a "full battery and equipments" were promised, we have associated comrades in arms and the friends of "better days," for the purpose of forming a first- class Artillery Company.
A communication of March 19th, from the Secretary of War, reassures us that the battery, &c., will be furnished.
In reply to the question q>"whether members of any Virginia company now in service would be permitted to re-enlist in the battery?" Gen. Randolph, in a letter of April 9th, says:"Twelve months volunteers may join the battery, but cannot be transferred until the expiration of their present term of service." We have in our projected organization seventy-seven re-enlisted men, drilled in light artillery besides a sufficient number of twelve months men to swell our list to about one hundred.
We wish to go into the field with one hundred and fifty first-class soldiers.
Men of unimpeached character, wishing to unite themselves with us in the service of the Confederate States for the war, will report the fact to their commanders, and to us at Suffolk, Va. We will organize permanently about the 12th of May, but men whose term of service expires after that date may be transferred to our company.
Prof. Massie has for the last six or eight months devoted himself to the study of light artillery tactics, gunnery, engineering, and the science of war generally, and his eminent and well-known proficiency in mathematics could but argue the most complete success and a bright future for himself and associates.

div3.head:
Second Company
Johnson's Light
Artillery.
div3.p:
More recruits are wanted for this company forthwith.
The conscription will soon be passed, mustering into the service every man in the Confederacy between the ages of 18 and 35, leaving no option with the conscript as to where he shall go, or to what arm of the service he shall belong.

All those who prefer to select the Light Artillery as their service should take at once the last opportunity they will probably have to volunteer.
We desire, at the earliest possible moment, to complete our organization and take the field, where all who are fit for service should be, and where they must be soon, either voluntarily or by compulsion.

Those who have been in service know that the Light Artillery is the most agreeable as well as the most effective arm of the service.
Come at once, then, while the chance is given you to enlist where you please, and relieve yourselves from the opprobrium of compulsory service.
Recruiting Office, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.

We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutenants of such a company, and have already a number of men enlisted.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, up stairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.

div3.p: I have been Authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Regiment of heavy Artillery for three years, or the war.

This regiment is rapidly filling up, and wants only a few companies requisite to its completion.
I should be glad to confer with captains who have companies, and also with those who desire to raise companies.

p.q: "Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years, or the war, will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered."

div3.p: Twelve months men can re-enlist singly or by companies for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty; and will also be transferred during the twenty days previous to the expiration of their present term.

div3.head: Battalion of Cavalry.
div3.p:
--In the month of February I received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or Regiment of Cavalry.
I have hesitated to under take to do so until this time, and I now propose to raise a Battalion of Cavalry.

Persons desiring to unite with me in this patriotic effort, and those wishing authority to recruit and raise companies, will address me at this place, or what is still better, report in person at once.
I expect to have two companies of infantry and one of artillery attached to my command.
Call at the office of the Battalion, Main street, Richmond, Va., opposite the office of the Southern Express Company.

div3.p: I am Authorized by the War Department to enlist and muster into service a Battalion of Infantry, to be armed and drilled as Foot Lancers or Pikemen, to fill up the 46th regiment of Virginia infantry, (commanded by Col. John H. Richardson)
For this Battalion, none other than young and active men will be received, those only who are both capable and willing to engage in an arduous and perilous service.
The 46th regiment is now on the Peninsula in front of the enemy, having already been engaged with their advanced forces.

It is, therefore, desirous to complete its complement as speedily as possible.
I shall be pleased to receive companies ready to be mustered into this battalion or regiment, or communications from officers proposing to raise such companies to be enlisted for the war.
Apply to me, personally, at my office, corner of Franklin and 6th sts., or by letter, to box 841, Post-Office.
